article.h1: Who can claim: Employees or employers

div.p: Employers rarely need to make overpayment relief claims.
See below for more information about

ul.li: employers making deductions in accordance with the PAYE regulations
employers making deductions not in accordance with the PAYE regulations
the exceptional situation where an employer makes an overpayment relief claim.

div.h2: Employer makes deductions in accordance with the PAYE regulations
div.p: The tax that an employer has to deduct and account for under PAYE may exceed an employee’s tax liability. This does not mean that the employer has paid more than the amount they were due to pay.
If an employer, in accordance with PAYE regulations, accounts for more than the employee’s tax liability, the employee reclaims the overpaid amounts.

ul.li: asking for their PAYE code to be amended during the year, see PAYE13075, or

making an informal claim after the year end (or before the year end if the person becomes unemployed or retires), see EIM71405 Link: https://www.gov.uk/hmrc-internal-manuals/employment-income-manual/eim71405 , EIM71405, or
submitting a self-assessment return after the year end, see EIM71410 Link: https://www.gov.uk/hmrc-internal-manuals/employment-income-manual/eim71410 . EIM71410.

div.p: If an employee makes a self-assessment but later finds that they have overpaid tax, they may be entitled to make a claim for overpayment relief if they can no longer amend their return.
div.h2: Employer makes deductions not in accordance with the PAYE regulations - no overpayment relief claim
div.p: If an employer deducts and accounts for more tax than is required under PAYE regulations, the employee normally

ul.li: receives repayments from either the employer during the year or HMRC after the year end, and
does not need to claim overpayment relief.

div.h2: Other overpayments by employers - no overpayment relief claim
div.p: You should deal with other overpayments by employers following the instructions on dealing with end of year returns at DMBM522290, without requiring an overpayment relief claim.
